C is for Cookie can be regarded as a case study in persuasive oratory, emphasizing the emotional aspect of public speaking. Cookie Monster builds excitement by answering his opening rhetorical question, "Now what starts with the letter C?" with the obvious reply, "Cookie starts with C!" He then challenges the audience, "Let's think of other things that starts with C," before quickly replying, "Oh, who cares about the other things?" casually dismissing a whole range of other possibilities as irrelevant. Thus, having ostensibly come for the purpose of covering the letter C in its entirety, Cookie Monster has already focused his agenda exclusively on cookies, employing the classic bait and switch tactic.  Several times in his presentation, Cookie Monster emphasizes what appears to be the central thesis of his remarks: "C is for cookie, that's good enough for me!" The appealing rhythm of this slogan appears designed to entrance listeners, swaying their emotions and making them instinctively want to chant along with him. After rousing the crowd, Cookie Monster systematically lays out the logical underpinnings of his pro-cookie ideology, comparing cookies to round donuts with one bite out of them and to the moon during its crescent phase, in essence using a straw man argument that implies his opponents would advocate the superiority of these competitors over cookies. In this sense, Cookie Monster may be proposing a false dichotomy representing cookies as the only viable choice to a group of obviously inferior alternatives.  But before the audience has a chance to catch on, Cookie Monster launches into another round of repetitive chanting, "C is for cookie, that's good enough for me, yeah!" as young children sing along. Here, Cookie Monster uses a propaganda technique strikingly similar to that employed in George Orwell's Animal Farm by the pig Napoleon, who trained the farm's sheep to bleat, "Four legs good, two legs bad" on his cue.  Cookie Monster then adds visual stimulation to his discourse by chomping into a large cookie, concluding his remarks with "Umm-umm-umm-umm-umm" and other chewing sounds.

oh yeah, I have more elaborations on it; there's this metaphor I came up with, which I call the gumball fallacy; people will say, "well, there's more vilagers than wolves right now, so if we lynch randomly, we're more likely to kill a villager than a wolf, and set ourselves back" -- by that logic, you'd never want to lynch randomly, because there are always more villagers than wolves in the game, unless wolves have parity, in which case, the game is over
basically if you lynch randomly, what you will tend to do is maintain the same ratio of villagers:wolves, but with fewer players

it's like if you had a gumball machine with 1,000 gumballs, 750 blue and 250 red -- if you take out 500 random gumballs, you'll still have the same ratio of 3:1 blue:red, even though any given time you take a gumball out, you're more likely to take out a blue than a red
so like if you take out 500, you'll have 375 blue and 125 red left; same ratio

well, same way with, say, a village of 24, with 18 village and 6 wolves -- if you use random lynches to reduce it in half, you end up with 12 players, 9 village and 3 wolves -- and eventually if you keep lynching you end up with 3 village, 1 wolf
and probably one of those villagers has a power role at the end, since typically 1 in 3 village will have some PR or another; in a village of 24 players, probably 6 have power roles
Pru stats do work better than speculating on pure behaviour stuff but IMO correct decision making does include taking cues and considering stat

the wolves have their night kills though which is like if there were a mischievous little kid breaking into your gumball machine at night and taking out only his favorites, the blue gumballs -- you'll end up with a lopsided ratio if he's doing that every day. So what you would want to do in that situation is try to sell gumballs the normal way as quickly as possible, to outpace his taking blue gumballs out selectively
I wonder if there is a paper out there simulating random lynch theory

oh yeah, they've done experiments using only vanillas and wolves; interestingly, because of how the numbers work out, you have better odds with, say, 6:1 villagers:wolves (46.67% win rate) than with 7:1 (37.5% win rate)
